Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: How People Become Urban

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project examines three pathways to becoming urban in an expanding city: being born in the city, migrating from a rural area to the city, and living in a formerly rural area that is swallowed up by the expanding borders of the city. The emphasis is on those who did not migrate but become urban through city expansion as they have been the least studied to date. The questions investigated concern how people understand local belonging, which people and what places are viewed as truly urban and local, who is viewed as part of an in-group or out-group, and who is deemed worthy of local citizenship rights and shared public spaces. Findings will be useful to policy makers and other concerned parties seeking to more effectively promote social inclusion in rapidly transforming cities.

Data collection for this project consists of fieldwork in a large and rapidly growing city. Spatial methods such as mental mapping exercises and city walks complement approximately 140 interviews: 40 interviews with each of the three kinds of city residents and 20 interviews with urban planning experts, drawn from different parts of the city. The interviews investigate how residents subjectively define the spatial and sociocultural boundaries that distinguish the urban and non-urban, the local and non-local, and the deserving and undeserving in their minds. Findings will yield a clearer picture of whether and why a sense of belonging or alienation persists among different types of city residents and how different kinds of city residents view the claims of others to citizenship.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We understand the challenges for assimilation when migrants move from rural to urban areas, but much less is understood about new urban migrants produced when city boundaries expand to include formerly rural areas.  This project examined such a case in a rapidly-urbanizing China, where an estimated 260 million or more migrants achieved urban residence because they were engulfed as rapidly-growing cities have expanded to encompass formerly-rural surrounding areas. Although all migrants share common social integration challenges and affect other group fates in the city, existing scholarship has said little about how these populations are viewed by each other and by native-born residents or about how people define local belonging when city boundaries are constantly in flux. This project studied how three different types of city residents —those produced by urban birth, by rural-to-urban migration, and those urbanized through city expansion—understand local belonging. Which people and places within a developing metropolitan area are viewed as truly urban and local? Who is viewed as part of an in-group or out-group, and who is deemed worthy of local citizenship rights and shared public spaces? Answers to these questions will help scholars and practitioners better understand the nature and origins of social divisions among different types of urban residents and more effectively promote social inclusion in rapidly-transforming cities.

The research team conducted 16 months of multiple-methods qualitative fieldwork based in the city of Chongqing, the fastest-growing municipality in China. 110 interviews were conducted with city residents and urban planning experts drawn from different parts of the city and were supplemented with mental mapping exercises and city walks. Interviews lasted an hour on average and were tape-recorded and professionally transcribed when allowed by participants. The research team is in the process of analyzing and writing up findings.

Overall, our hypothesis that respondents’ subjective definitions of what people and places counted as truly “rural”/“urban” and “local”/”non-local” often differed from “objective” legal classifications. For instance, many urban-born residents continued to view other rural-born migrants to the city as “rural” people (often calling them pejorative names) even after said migrants achieved legal urban citizenship status (via obtaining hukou, or household-registration). Findings like this are significant because many studies conducted by scholars and statistical data collected by the government classify people as “rural”/”urban” based upon people’s legal hukou status. My findings suggest that such studies/surveys may not capture the full picture of who actually experiences discrimination and disadvantage. My findings suggest that despite efforts by the government to reduce the salience and importance of place identity through hukou reform, place identy remains and important and causally consequential cultural category. People’s classifications of who is truly “rural”/”urban” and “local”/”non-local” continues to impact how people judge and associate with another on an individual level and by extension, group-level outcomes such as social networks, collective efficacy, and social conflict.

Our study makes a case for the usefulness of attending to ordinary people’s own subjective views rather than reifying and taking for granted legal-official categories when studying social integration. While this project is a case study on Chongqing, China, we argue that such an approach is likely to become increasingly relevant to other situations across the globe as migration and urbanization accelerates amid climate change.
